item.title: Lesson 1: Crown of the Head
item.description: Download Lesson 1: Crown of the Head here. (right click to save) In your first workout, give yourself plenty of time to settle in. Each week, I will send you a new workout via email.

item.title: The Power of Standing Qigong as a Gateway to Meditative Stillness

item.description: The easiest way to work through the Energy Gates Dissolving Series - like having a teacher by your side the whole time! Week-by-week, as you clear the gates, you will find new space inside the body, release bound or stuck chi, and realign the twists, kinks, and compressions that warp the body -- physically and energetically.

item.title: Start Your Standing Meditation Practice Now
item.description: Basic Standing Qigong Posture Congratulations on starting your standing meditation practice! As you can see from the picture on the right, "standing" is easy. Just begin in a relaxed, arms-by-the-sides posture, with your eyes closed. Pay attention to these 3 important postural points: Unlock the knees and hips. Let the weight fall into the arches of each foot, not back to the heels. Relax the chest and muscles of the face and breath smoothly, without a lot of force or effort.

item.title: The Five Keys to Taoist Energy Arts
item.description:
Energy Arts Senior Instructor Paul Cavel recently released his "Five Keys to the Taoist Energy Arts." If I had to put together a complete foundational program for learning qigong or Tai Chi, this is exactly what I'd include. What's inside the Five Keys: Breathing Energy Work Standing Meditation Smooth Circular Movement.
In short, all the foundations for a great qigong program! As you know from many episodes of Qigong Radio, I turn to Paul whenever I want a clear and structured explanation of a dimension of my practice (check out these episodes on body development and meditation).

item.title: Paul Cavel's Inner Quest Journal
item.description: Each month, Energy Arts Senior Instructor Paul Cavel publishes a newsletter packed full of articles about neigong, qigong, Tai Chi, and Ba Gua.If you want to deeply understand the philosophy underlying your practice, you'll love his Inner Quest Journal. Each issue includes: Articles, interviews and/or podcasts on nei gong energy arts, I Ching arts and Tao meditation The supporting roles of nature, nutrition and community, such as coverage of Five Element Theory, to boost practice results Taoist creation, cosmology and I Ching studies East meets West perspectives on specific injuries, including examining prevention and healing protocols Article contributions from experienced internal energy arts and meditation instructors Inspiring personal stories Your personal questions answered by Paul

item.title: Introduction to Tai Chi Rooting
item.description: In "An Introduction to Rooting and Stability," you will be introduced to the ancient Chinese method for gaining, or re-gaining, one of life's simplest yet most essential treasures--the gift of balance. These Tai Chi Balance Exercises by themselves form a beginning program that will produce a noticeable improvement in your sense of being grounded, or connected to the earth, centrally stabilized around a vertical axis, and able to change visual orientation while remaining balanced.

item.title: Springy Knees in Tai Chi
item.description: If you remember the original Star Wars® movie it is probably easy to remember the ‘droid C3PO and his strange gait. This android lacked the proper joint arrangement to move in a proper way, which made his walk seem stiff and difficult. But while his spine seemed stiff his knees worked quite well. The reason for this seeming anomaly is that the proper functioning of the knee is critical to effective movement.

item.title: What Will a Fall Cost You?
Qigong Exercises to Open the Spine
item.description: People fall. The fall might be caused by a slip or trip or even an inner ear imbalance. Normally when we think someone falling we think of either the elderly or very young children still finding their balance. But according to the World Health Organization (WHO) falls are much more of a problem for all ages than most people realize. The organization said: · Nearly half a million people globally die from falls each year.
